awd_titl_txt: Exploring Gravitational and Nuclear Physics with Gravitational Wave Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project integrates a research program to reveal the extreme nature of gravity and dense matter from gravitational wave observations with outreach events on planetarium shows, public lectures and summer camps to expose the public to frontier research fields in physics. Such an integrated program is extremely timely, as gravitational waves were detected directly for the first time in September 2015 using LIGO, which has long been funded by NSF, and the era of gravitational wave and multimessenger astronomy has begun. The project addresses fundamental questions in gravitational and nuclear physics: (I) Is General Relativity correct in the strong and dynamical field regime of gravity? (II) What is the nature of supranuclear matter? The proposed research establishes a new framework for probing the extreme nature of gravity and dense matter physics with gravitational wave observations. Such a research program will significantly enhance the ability of extracting the scientific return from current and future observations. Understanding the extreme nature of gravity and dense matter may bring implications also to other fields, including particle and high energy physics and cosmology. The outreach part of the project tries to develop public's interests, curiosity and enthusiasms in science by connecting them to the frontier scientific research on gravitational waves through multiple outreach events. Such activities allow the PI and collaborators to directly reach, inspire and excite, in particular, the next generation of scientists.

The research objectives are (i) to maximize the ability of extracting gravitational physics information from the currently-available gravitational wave data, (ii) to consider new sources of gravitational waves as probes of strong and dynamical field gravity and (iii) to reveal how accurately one can determine the equation of state for supranuclear matter with current and future gravitational wave observations. PI Yagi will take the following methodology to achieve the above research goals. On the gravitational physics front, the PI's team will focus on studying corrections away from General Relativity entering in the amplitude of gravitational waveforms that have mostly been neglected. The team will also consider astrophysical stochastic backgrounds as new sources of gravitational waves to probe strong and dynamical field gravity. On the nuclear physics front, PI Yagi and collaborators will carry out a detailed Bayesian parameter estimation study by including spin precession and adopting universal relations for neutron stars that do not depend strongly on the unknown equation of state. They will also study universal relations among tidal parameters and nuclear physics parameters so that one can directly probe the latter with gravitational wave observations. The educational part of the proposal aims at conveying the historical discovery of gravitational waves and the beauty of General Relativity to the public. PI Yagi and collaborators will achieve this goal by displaying a planetarium show created by collaborator Yunes at Montana State University at several different planetarium domes in Virginia, including those at James Madison University and Radford University. The PI and collaborators at James Madison University will also host a summer camp on General Relativity and gravitational waves for middle-school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
“Exploring Gravitational and Nuclear Physics with Gravitational Wave Astronomy'' (PI: Kent Yagi) integrates a research program to reveal the extreme nature of gravity and dense matter from gravitational wave observations with outreach events on planetarium shows to expose the public to frontier research fields in physics.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

 The PI worked in three main directions, (i) testing General Relativity with gravitational waves in a theory-agnostic way, (ii) testing General Relativity with gravitational waves in specific gravitational theories, and (iii) probing nuclear physics with gravitational wave and multimessenger astronomy.

 

Regarding the first direction, the PI developed the mapping between specific theories and a model-independent framework for testing gravity with gravitational waves. The PI then carried out a gravitational-wave data analysis to reveal how well current and future gravitational-wave observations can probe General Relativity. The PI found that future detectors can probe the strong-field gravity by a few orders of magnitude more precisely than ground-based detectors. Furthermore, a combination of ground-based detectors (like LIGO) and space-based ones (like LISA) is crucial in probing one of the fundamental pillars in General Relativity that is related to the mirror symmetry of spacetime (called parity).

 

Regarding the second direction, the PI focused on testing a gravitational theory beyond General Relativity that is motivated by string theory. The PI first derived gravitational waveforms from collisions of black holes and neutron stars in this theory including higher-order effects. The PI then carried out a gravitational-wave data analysis and derived a bound on the theory that is one of the most stringent ones to date.

 

Regarding the third direction, the PI studied the correlations between nuclear parameters and neutron star observables, like the tidal deformability measured with gravitational-wave observations or the radius measured by X-ray observations. The PI then used observational data and measured one of the nuclear parameters (that is difficult to measure with terrestrial experiments) through multimessenger observations (a combination of gravitational wave and electromagnetic observations). The PI also studied how well one can probe the possibility of neutron stars having a crystallized quark core as motivated by some nuclear theory. The PI and his student computed characteristic stellar oscillation modes that are encoded in gravitational waves from binary neutron star mergers and showed that one can already rule out some of the nuclear/quark parameter space with the existing gravitational wave events.

 

Broader Impact

 

The PI carried out two planetarium events. The first event, which was open to the public, was held at Radford University on October 30, 2021. With the help of Prof. Rhett Herman, the director of Planetarium at Radford University, the PI hosted a planetarium show on gravitational waves (created by the team led by Prof. Nicolas Yunes, currently at UIUC) three times. Each show was followed by a presentation, a Q&A session, and pop quizzes, all led by the PI. There were 40 people in total who participated in pop quizzes. There were seven academic questions and for some of them, such as “What is the size of spacetime fluctuation LIGO detected when GWs passed it?”, all the participants got the right answer (“smaller than the size of a proton”). This clearly shows that the audience learned some important facts related to gravitational wave physics and some of the animations that the PI presented in the show and presentation worked out well. 97.4% of them said the event helped to stimulate their excitement about science, 97.4% of them said they felt they got the basic idea of General Relativity, and 100% of them agreed the event was satisfactory.

 

The second event was held at James Madison University on April 1, 2023. This time, the audience was physics teachers in the Chesapeake Section and the event was a part of the Chesapeake Section of the American Association of Physics Teachers (CSAAPT) Spring Meeting. The presentation and Q&A session were led by PI’s graduate students at UVA. 14 people participated in pop quizzes and the questions were the same as the Radford ones. 85.7% of them said the event helped to stimulate their excitement about science, 85.7% of them said they felt they got the basic idea of General Relativity, and 92.9% of them agreed the event was satisfactory. Based on these results, the events seem successful in leveraging the public’s interests in science and enhancing awareness and appreciation of frontier scientific research.
